segments.text: Let me get things cranked up here.
Yeah.
What do you want to tell me?
What you going to ask me?
Yeah.
That makes no difference though.
Okay.
Um, basically, uh, how long have you been living in Cross Plains?
I've been living in Cross Plains.
I've lived here since 1922.
Uh, that would be about, uh, good Lord.
That's a while in it.
Yeah.
Uh, I was a boy here and, uh,
went to college and came back, took over the newspaper, got out of college one day and took over the newspaper, hit the next one.
Been here all the while.
I retired in the newspaper about eight or nine years ago.
When did you first meet Mr. Howard?
When did I first meet him?
Well, as a boy, I knew him here.
When he was a boy, Howard would be about, Howard's about four or five years old or nine, four years I guess.
I guess he'd be about, I'm 70 years old.
I would be about 74 or 5 now, I think.
Okay.
I could check that out for you, but possibly you got that information at hand.
Yes.
When did you... I knew him at... I started to high school.
Let's see.
I came in here, moved here from a nearby town and entered high school as about a sophomore.
And those days we only had ten grades here and they were not affiliated.
But Howard went down to Brownwood to finish his high school work in order to be qualified, you know, to enter college.
When you came back to Cross Plains after going to college and you started over the newspaper, that was in July, I took over the newspaper in July 1930.
Howard was here at the time.
He was a young man, I was 20 years old and Howard must have been 24 or 5.
He was writing for a bunch of pulp magazines, just getting started.
And very few people remember the names of those magazines, but it was Stone Street and Smith.
They published a number of magazines, like Weird Tales.
Weird Tales was one of them, I believe.
Boxing in the west, the wild west, and a whole lot of stuff like that.
He mainly wrote for weird tales, but he also occasionally wrote for... He's either a ring or something.
He occasionally wrote for a boxing magazine, too.
Yeah, we were talking to Ms.
Laughlin.
She said sometimes he would go down the streets there shadow boxing and sort of doing a little... Yeah, I imagine that's more or less exaggerated.
Hard was a little on...
a little on the outside.
He wasn't in them, but it was very many people.
He was rather aloof.
But he was a big, robust man.
To me, he was a combination of Edgar Allen Poe and Jack London, if you can imagine that two together.
Yeah, he had those books in his library, so I can imagine that pretty well.
He was very robust, like Jack London.
He was

Uh, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it's him, imagine it
Yeah, I do believe I have read that one.
Yeah, I'm sure you've read it.
We're very many people on cross planes aware that Howard was a writer or I guess... Oh, they all knew it.
I published in the newspaper, you know, there wasn't a lot.
I'd say that Robert Howard had a story this week and Weird Tales or some of those pop magazines, yeah, they knew it.
Yeah, yeah, I take it being a small town, I guess, just about everybody knew everything else.
Oh, yeah, that's right.
And his dad, he was a doctor here, a country doctor, general practitioner, well thought of, very popular.
And his father was proud of the fact that his son was a gifted writer.
He talked about it.
Yeah.
Well, let's see.
I'm about to run through my gambit of questions here.
Was there anything
Any particular stories you know about Mr. Howard being that you were a newspaper man and everything?
He might have had some exploits out there.
I remember the morning he killed himself very well.
I can't think just what it was.
I know it was a warm season of the year, it must have been summer.
But anyway, early in the summer, 10, 11 o'clock in the morning,
I heard on the street that Robert Howard had just shot himself when I immediately jumped in my car and ran down there and got down there and a few neighbors had gathered.
It wasn't generally known over town, but the old justice of the peace was standing there on the gallery, the front porch.
When I walked up, he called and said, come here, Jack.
And I stepped up there and he took me into the bedroom and he
He pointed to an old Underwood top rider who had the four lines written on it there.
And Howard had, when he had been told that his mother wouldn't live throughout the day, he went to this top rider, wrote these four lines, walked outside, sat down his car and shot his head off.
And this old JP asked me what these four lines meant.
They said, I'm sure you've read them all flat all done, so let me on the pyre.
The feast is over, the lamps expire.
Yeah, we have read that, that's all.
I'm sure you've read that.

To me, I've been told since then by Sprayk de Kemp that the lions are not entirely original, but they were certainly original as far as I'd ever heard, or anybody else I've ever talked to except Sprayk de Kemp.
Yeah, I imagine that's...
was Howard's way of putting it.
Yeah, that was his.
That was his melodic dream.
Yeah.
His finale.
Well, Mr. Scott, I can't think of anything else.
Can you think of any other bold thing?
I'll tell you, you've got a son of Aaron Odessa.
I'll tell you, a young man there, an Odessa.
You can pick up on the telephone and call him and knew him.
His name is Jay Brown, the B-A-U-M bomb.
He's a man he's 70 years old.
He's just my age.
Uh, as a boy, he knew Robert Howard.
His name is Jay Baum.
Jay.
Brown.
B-R-O-D-N-E.
Brown.
B-A-U-M.
His son is a, his son is a loan officer and one of the, uh, one of the, uh, one of the, uh, one of those things out there.
I don't know which one.
Yo, I'll see if I can track him down too.
We talked with Charlotte Laughlin and some other people in Brownwood who were doing some research on the show.
Have you talked to CF Borg?
No sir, we talked to Jack Scott.
Yeah, I know Jack.
They're in Cross Plains and he referred us to you and your brother.
And what we're mainly just looking for are just some O's and some
Interesting stories or any reminisces you might have about Mr. Howard?
Well, yes, I'd be glad to tell you what I know about him.
I try to think of some things that happened.
He was an unusual fellow, I know that.
Have you read some of his stories?
Yes, I have.
What type of person was he?
Well, he was kind of a loner.
I'll just recount on it.
I don't think he ever went for the girl at all.
But he wrote some pretty outstanding stories.
Well, as I was saying, I recall some of the stories he wrote when he was in high school.
And they were really outstanding, but he never did.
Uh, he really wasn't in our group.
He was kind of a outsider.

Yes, he was readily accepted, but I remember one time, uh, we were having a party and, uh, I was running a little rental store there in Cross Plains and we were having a party upstairs and Robert came and we were, we were drinking some beer, choc beer or something.
as way back before prohibition.
And I know he got very upset about it.
He got a little bit tired and he said that he'd kill anybody that interfered with his hands.
If his hands ever got damaged by somebody else, then he'd kill them.
Hello?
Yes, sir.
And that was just kind of what he was, kind of morose.
And he thought he had a real bright future in the head of him as a writer.
And I don't think I ever saw him after that, until I heard he had committed suicide, didn't he?
Yes, he did.
I knew his father real well.
I didn't know his mother much.
I know he was an only child, I believe.
And he never did enter into any of our activities very much as I remember.
So I don't really know if I could just tell you that it would help you.
Well, what you've already told us is quite a bit of help.
Why do you suppose he was such a loner?
Being in front of such a small town and usually everybody, you know, does things so much together?
I don't know.
I don't know.
He could have been a great author, I think.
He had a... I don't remember even what kind of grades he made academically.
I know I took an ID, he had a story, and tried to write a theme on it, and he'd already turned it down.
And I got in big trouble there, as you know, trying to steal his ideas.

And that kind of, I never did try that anymore again, but I know he could tell a story that was really, this was something about a bear who got up in the attic or something and broke through and disturbed some poker players.
But then I really can't tell you very much about Robert.
I'm thinking of it.
There's another writer, C.S.
Boyle, I don't know if you ever heard of him.
Uh, no, sir.
No, I don't believe so, no.
Mostly, uh, he had worked a little bit for Jack on the newspaper and, uh, well, Jack talked about, uh, what type of person he was, uh,

I wish I could recall more about that party, but I know he scared the hell out of all of us, because he got really excited and thought he was trying to damage his riding career or something, getting him full of beer.
I don't recall exactly what, but anyway, he said he'd kill anybody that
damage his hands anyway.
I seem like I remember that pretty vividly.
I don't know, maybe something happened there with his hands.
Maybe we got him wracking match or something.
I don't know.
But anyway, he wanted to ride with his hands.
That's very interesting.
You don't happen to ride like any other
things that you might have done with Howard back when we were living across.
Well, like I say, he wasn't in our group.
We went fishing, we went swimming in the bow there, and we hunted quail, but he was never one of us.
And now he happened to be in this deal.
I don't know, I don't think he ever had the date with a girl.
He was a nice looking guy.
very presentable and tall and well-made.
And even if I talk to you, I can't really tell you anything much that I remember about him except that I remember him being a very outstanding, that he would have been a great writer, I think.
Listen, what you've told me so far has been quite helpful.
We're putting together just bits and pieces of people who did know him, along with some research that some other people have done.
And I'd like to go ahead and put your recollections of that party and some of the other things you said into our program.
Well, that's authentic, but I can't quite recall the details of what happened to his hands.
Maybe we were armwrestling or something.
I don't know.
But he got very uptight about what might happen to
One of his hands or his arms or something.
I guess that was the only time he ever had a drink of beer in his life.
It sounded like what I was talking to some of the other people that he might have been kind of insecure.
Well, I think so.
He was an only child.
I know that.
I don't know how close he was with his mother, but I don't think his father had anything to do with him.
It was my kind of feeling, I don't know.
Dr. Howard was a real fine man, though I don't know how close they were together, but I think that he worshipped his mother was my impression in those years.
I don't know whether she died first or not, do you?
She had gone into a coma and was not expected to recover.
Oh, well now that's the reason for the suicide.
because he worshipped her.
I know I can almost be sure of that, but he worshipped his mother.
And I know that her condition affected him very much.
And I know that he was real afraid that something would happen that he couldn't write in.
whether it was mine or whether it was in his mind or whether it was in his fear that something would happen to his hands.
But that sense is that I recall more vividly than anything else and I've often thought of it.
I certainly do appreciate your talking with me.
And I believe I was the one that, I believe that he could have strangled me to death there.
I don't recall.
He was a very big and strong fellow.
Yes, very strong.
Could have twisted your neck off.
Much like the heroes that he wrote about.
If you give me your address, I'll send you a release form.
What that does is simply you give us permission to use what I've been taping.
Oh, well, that doesn't matter to me.
I don't care if I use it or not.
I'm just trying to be honest with you.
And I have no hold on it.
You can quote me any way you want to do it.
And as I say, it's been a long time ago, but those are my recollections and I've often thought I've made a real strong impression on these.
that I was in real danger there.
Well, fortunately you made it through it.
Other things have happened to me that I guess almost is dangerous, but then anyway, that's what I remember about Robert.
Truth, all that was no problem, apparently, and no attachments that I know of to anybody except
